complimentary.definition: A complimentary item or service is provided for free.
example_sentences: At the quaint little inn, guests were greeted with a complimentary glass of wine upon arrival.

coke and fries.definition: Coke and fries refers to a common pairing of a Coca-Cola and a serving of chips, often enjoyed as a quick snack or part of a casual meal.
example_sentences: After the football match, we stopped at a cafe for coke and fries.

still working on sth..definition: If someone says they are still working on it, it means they are continuing to work on a task and have not yet finished.
example_sentences: When asked about the status of his report, John replied that he was still working on it.
still working on sth..Chinese: 还在需要一些时间完成报告

go with sth..definition: If you go with something, it means you choose or select it as your option.
example_sentences: For the main course, I think I'll go with the roast beef.

go grab sth..definition: If you go grab something, you quickly and informally go to get or buy it.
example_sentences: Could you go grab some milk on your way back? We're almost out.

quite ill.definition: If someone is quite ill, they are very sick, often implying a significant degree of illness.
example_sentences: He was quite ill last week and had to miss several days of school.

call in sick.definition: If you call in sick, you inform your workplace that you are ill and unable to attend work.
example_sentences: After waking up feeling dreadful, Sarah decided she had to call in sick and rest.

come down with sth..definition: If you come down with something, it means you begin to suffer from an illness, typically suddenly.
example_sentences: Halfway through the term, he came down with the flu and missed several lectures.

feverish.definition: If someone is feverish, they have a fever and may feel hotter than usual, often as part of an illness.
example_sentences: The child felt feverish in the night, prompting a call to the doctor first thing in the morning.

a reservation under the name.definition: If you have a reservation under the name, it means you have booked or reserved a service or place, such as a table or a room, registered under that specific name.
example_sentences: Upon arriving at the restaurant, he told the host, 'I have a reservation under the name Smith.'
a reservation under the name.usage: have a reservation under the name Smith
a reservation under the name.Chinese: 在Smith的名下订了一个房间

a mix-up.definition: A mix-up is a situation where a misunderstanding or mistake has caused confusion.
example_sentences: Due to a mix-up in the schedule, both meetings were booked for the same conference room.

be overbooked.definition: If a service or venue is overbooked, it means that more reservations were accepted than there is available capacity.
example_sentences: The flight to Edinburgh was overbooked, so the airline offered vouchers to passengers willing to take a later departure.
be overbooked.usage: a restaurant that is overbooked every day
be overbooked.Chinese: 一间每天都被订满的饭店

resources.definition: Resources are supplies, materials, or money that are available for use to achieve goals or complete tasks.
example_sentences: The charity had limited resources but managed to make a significant impact with what they had.
resources.usage: allocate more resources to the project
resources.Chinese: 在这个项目上花更多的钱

be understaffed.definition: If a business or organisation is understaffed, it does not have enough employees to operate effectively.
example_sentences: The shop was understaffed on Saturday, which led to longer waiting times for customers.

the timing is just not right.definition: If you say the timing is just not right, you mean that it is not a suitable or appropriate moment for a particular action or event.
example_sentences: He wanted to launch the new product in April, but I felt the timing was just not right.
the timing is just not right.usage: refuse him by saying the timing is just not right
the timing is just not right.Chinese: 拒绝了他，说时机还不成熟

take some of the weight off one's should.definition: If you take some of the weight off someone's shoulders, you reduce their burden or responsibility.
example_sentences: When Jane offered to help with the project, it really took some of the weight off my shoulders.
take some of the weight off one's should.usage: take some of the weight off his shoulders

give sb. a hand.definition: If you give someone a hand, you help them with a task.
example_sentences: Could you give me a hand with these boxes? They're rather heavy to move alone.
give sb. a hand.usage: give me a hand with the luggage

be a mile long.definition: If something is described as being a mile long, it means it is extremely long, often in a hyperbolic sense.
example_sentences: The queue for the concert tickets was a mile long; it seemed everyone in town wanted to go.
be a mile long.usage: surprised to see the to-do list that must be a mile long
be a mile long.Chinese: 看到那份长长的待办事项单，感到很吃惊

cut in line.definition: If someone cuts in line, they unfairly move in front of others who are waiting in order, typically in a queue.
example_sentences: It's quite rude to cut in line; please wait your turn like everyone else.
cut in line.usage: cut in line at the supermarket

there's no way.definition: The phrase 'there's no way' expresses impossibility or extreme unlikelihood of an event occurring.
example_sentences: There's no way we can finish all this work by the end of the day without some extra help.
there's no way.usage: realised there's no way to meet the deadline
there's no way.Chinese: 意识到不可能在截止日期前完成

jump the queue.definition: If someone jumps the queue, they unfairly move ahead of others who have been waiting in line longer.
example_sentences: At the bus stop, a gentleman tried to jump the queue, causing quite a stir among the waiting passengers.
jump the queue.usage: jump the queue at the post office

be packed.definition: If a place is packed, it is extremely full, usually with people.
example_sentences: The pub was packed on Friday night, making it difficult to find a seat.
be packed.usage: the museum that is packed with pupils

munchies.definition: Munchies are snacks, especially those eaten between meals or late at night.
example_sentences: During the film, we enjoyed some crisps and sweets, the perfect munchies for a movie night.

fill up the tank.definition: If you fill up the tank, you put fuel in a vehicle's fuel tank until it is full.
example_sentences: Before the long drive, we made sure to fill up the tank to avoid stopping midway.
fill up the tank.usage: fill up the tank before setting off

be all set.definition: If someone is all set, they are fully prepared or ready for something.
example_sentences: Once the luggage was in the car, we were all set for our holiday.
be all set.usage: be all set for the holiday

get all the bases covered.definition: If you get all the bases covered, you ensure that all aspects of a situation have been considered or dealt with.
example_sentences: Before launching the product, the team met to ensure they had all the bases covered.
get all the bases covered.usage: get all the bases covered for the event
get all the bases covered.Chinese: 为活动做好了所有准备

get going.definition: If someone gets going, they start moving or begin a journey.
example_sentences: It's getting late; we should really get going if we want to be there on time.
get going.usage: get going before it gets dark

a pit stop.definition: A pit stop is a brief stop during a journey, typically to use the restroom or get food or fuel.
example_sentences: We took a quick pit stop at the service station to stretch our legs and buy some coffee.

highway toll.definition: A highway toll is a fee charged for using certain roads, typically motorways or bridges.
example_sentences: When driving to Scotland, one must be prepared to pay the highway toll near Birmingham.

rental car.definition: A rental car is a vehicle hired from a company for a temporary period, used primarily by travellers.
example_sentences: During our trip to Lake District, we used a rental car to explore the remote areas.

trunk.definition: The trunk is the compartment at the rear of a vehicle used for storing luggage and other items.
example_sentences: Please put your suitcase in the trunk; there's plenty of space for it.

form a queue.definition: If people form a queue, they line up one behind the other, usually to wait for goods or services.
example_sentences: At the theatre, patrons were asked to form a queue at the box office.
form a queue.usage: form a queue at the ticket counter

concierge.definition: A concierge is a hotel employee who assists guests by making reservations, giving directions, and arranging transportation.
example_sentences: The concierge was most helpful in booking us a table at the highly recommended restaurant nearby.

make it into work.definition: If you make it into work, you manage to arrive at your workplace, typically implying difficulties in doing so.
example_sentences: Despite the heavy snow, she managed to make it into work on time.
make it into work.usage: make it into work despite the traffic
make it into work.Chinese: 尽管交通拥堵，还是准时到了上班的地方

freeze.definition: If a computer freezes, it stops working properly and becomes unresponsive.
example_sentences: My computer froze while I was in the middle of writing an important email.

infected file.definition: An infected file is a file on a computer that contains a virus or malicious software.
example_sentences: The antivirus programme detected an infected file and removed it immediately.

up to date.definition: If something is up to date, it has all the most recent information or is modern.
example_sentences: Make sure your software is up to date to protect against security vulnerabilities.
up to date.usage: keep the system up to date
up to date.Chinese: 保持系统处于最新的状态

act up.definition: If something acts up, it does not work properly or behaves erratically.
example_sentences: My car started acting up on the way to work, so I had to take it to the mechanic.

be right up.definition: If someone says they will be right up, they mean they will go upstairs very soon.
example_sentences: I'll be right up with your tea, just need to finish washing these dishes.
be right up.usage: be right up with the drinks
be right up.Chinese: 马上就会把饮料端上楼

pick up.definition: If you pick something up, you get or acquire it.
example_sentences: I need to pick up some milk from the corner shop on my way home.
pick up.usage: pick up some milk from the store

in a bit of a hurry.definition: If someone is in a bit of a hurry, they do not have much time and need to rush.
example_sentences: Sorry, I can't stop to chat - I'm in a bit of a hurry to catch my train.
in a bit of a hurry.usage: be in a bit of a hurry to catch the bus

slip one's mind.definition: If something slips one's mind, it is forgotten.
example_sentences: I meant to call you yesterday, but it completely slipped my mind.
slip one's mind.usage: Your name just slipped my mind.

around here.definition: If something is around here, it is close to or near this place.
example_sentences: There are some lovely parks around here that are perfect for a weekend stroll.

be terrible with.definition: If someone is terrible with something, they are very bad at it.
example_sentences: I'm terrible with names; I often forget them right after being introduced.

inconsiderate.definition: If someone is inconsiderate, they do not think about the feelings or needs of others.
example_sentences: It was rather inconsiderate of him to play loud music late at night.

keep it down.definition: If you tell someone to keep it down, you are asking them to be quiet.
example_sentences: Could you keep it down, please? I'm trying to concentrate on my work.
keep it down.usage: ask him to keep it down

not such a big deal.definition: If something is not such a big deal, it is not a significant problem.
example_sentences: Don't worry about the mistake in the report; it's not such a big deal.
not such a big deal.usage: not such a big deal to miss the bus
not such a big deal.Chinese: 错过公车不是什么大事

can't hear a thing.definition: If someone says they can't hear a thing, they are unable to hear anything.
example_sentences: I can't hear a thing with all this noise from the construction outside.
can't hear a thing.usage: can't hear a thing with the music on
can't hear a thing.Chinese: 开着音乐什么都听不见

good riddance.definition: If you say 'good riddance', you mean that you are glad to be rid of someone or something unpleasant.
example_sentences: When he finally left the company, everyone said, 'Good riddance!'

good grief.definition: If you say 'good grief', you are expressing surprise or shock.
example_sentences: Good grief, how did you manage to finish that project so quickly?

sth. comes to grief.definition: If something comes to grief, it fails or ends in a bad way.
example_sentences: Their business venture came to grief when they ran out of funding.
sth. comes to grief.usage: feel sad when the project comes to grief
sth. comes to grief.Chinese: 当项目失败了以后感到难过

put someone out of his misery.definition: If you put someone out of their misery, you end their suffering by resolving a difficult situation for them.
example_sentences: After weeks of uncertainty, she finally put him out of his misery and told him he had got the job.
put someone out of his misery.usage: put him out of his misery and tell him the truth
put someone out of his misery.Chinese: 告诉他真相，别吊他的胃口了

equilibrium.definition: Someone's equilibrium is their normal calm state of mind.
example_sentences: She took a few deep breaths to regain her equilibrium before speaking.

in remembrance of sth..definition: If you do something in remembrance of someone or something, you do it to honour their memory.
example_sentences: The plaque was erected in remembrance of the soldiers who fought in the war.
in remembrance of sth..usage: a statue in remembrance of the fallen

spark the trend of sth..definition: If something sparks the trend of something, it starts a new popular activity or fashion.
example_sentences: Her unique fashion sense sparked the trend of vintage clothing among teenagers.
spark the trend of sth..usage: spark the trend of pyjama dressing
spark the trend of sth..Chinese: 引领了睡衣搭配的潮流

be quoted as saying that.definition: If someone is quoted as saying something, their exact words are repeated.
example_sentences: The Prime Minister was quoted as saying that the new policy would benefit the whole country.
be quoted as saying that.usage: be quoted as saying that the project was a success

sth. occurs to sb..definition: If something occurs to someone, they suddenly think of it.
example_sentences: It suddenly occurred to him that he had forgotten to lock the door.
sth. occurs to sb..usage: became nervous when the thought occurred to him
sth. occurs to sb..Chinese: 在他脑中突然闪过这个念头时变得紧张

bump into sb..definition: If you bump into someone, you meet them unexpectedly.
example_sentences: I bumped into an old friend while walking through the park.

answer for sth..definition: If you answer for something, you are responsible for it and may be required to explain your actions.
example_sentences: He will have to answer for his mistakes when the manager returns.

be visible to sb..definition: If something is visible to someone, it can be seen or noticed by them.
example_sentences: The landmark was visible to everyone from miles around.
be visible to sb..usage: be visible to the tourists from the top of the hill

dismiss sth. as pure speculation.definition: If you dismiss something as pure speculation, you reject it as a baseless or unfounded guess.
example_sentences: The scientist dismissed the rumours of a breakthrough as pure speculation.
dismiss sth. as pure speculation.usage: dismiss the rumours as pure speculation
dismiss sth. as pure speculation.Chinese: 否认了谣言，说这纯属猜测

put off.definition: If you put off something, you delay it or postpone it to a later time.
example_sentences: They decided to put off the meeting until next week.
put off.usage: put off the meeting until tomorrow

ever-present.definition: If something is ever-present, it is always there or always present.
example_sentences: The ever-present smell of fresh bread was comforting.
ever-present.usage: the ever-present problem of traffic congestion
ever-present.Chinese: 一直存在的交通拥堵问题

scramble to do sth..definition: If you scramble to do something, you move or act quickly because you are in a hurry.
example_sentences: The team scrambled to finish the project before the deadline.

intrude on sth..definition: If you intrude on something, you disturb or interrupt it in an unwelcome way.
example_sentences: He didn't want to intrude on their private conversation.

make way for sth..definition: If you make way for something, you move aside to allow it to pass or make progress.
example_sentences: The old building was demolished to make way for a new shopping centre.
make way for sth..usage: make way for the new generation

stuff sth. with sth..definition: If you stuff something with something, you fill it tightly with a material or substance.
example_sentences: She stuffed the pillow with feathers to make it more comfortable.

be riddled with.definition: If something is riddled with something, it is full of or affected by numerous instances of it.
example_sentences: The old house was riddled with damp and needed extensive repairs.

be related to.definition: If something is related to another thing, it has a connection with it.
example_sentences: Her job is related to environmental conservation.

draw up the contract.definition: If you draw up the contract, you prepare or write it.
example_sentences: The solicitor was asked to draw up the contract for the new house.
draw up the contract.usage: draw up the contract for the new project

fall victim to.definition: If someone falls victim to something, they suffer as a result of it.
example_sentences: Many people fall victim to online scams each year.
fall victim to.usage: fall victim to the delayed train

usher in.definition: If you usher in something, you cause it to start or happen.
example_sentences: The new technology is expected to usher in an era of economic growth.

rough neighbourhood.definition: A rough neighbourhood is an area that is considered dangerous or unpleasant to live in.
example_sentences: They grew up in a rough neighbourhood but managed to succeed despite the challenges.
rough neighbourhood.usage: avoid living in the rough neighbourhood
rough neighbourhood.Chinese: 避免住在乱糟糟的地方

the first of its kind.definition: If something is the first of its kind, it is unique and has never been done or made before.
example_sentences: The new electric car model was the first of its kind in the market.
the first of its kind.usage: the first of its kind in the industry

be packed with.definition: If something is packed with something, it is full of or contains a large amount of it.
example_sentences: The festival was packed with exciting activities and performances.

hammer away at.definition: If you hammer away at something, you work at it steadily and with great determination.
example_sentences: She hammered away at her dissertation for months until it was finally completed.

feast on sth..definition: If you feast on something, you eat a large amount of it with great enjoyment.
example_sentences: They feasted on a traditional Christmas dinner with all the trimmings.

stick to sth..definition: If you stick to something, you continue doing it despite difficulties or distractions.
example_sentences: He decided to stick to his exercise routine, even during the busy holiday season.

make for.definition: Make for means to contribute to or lead to a particular outcome.
example_sentences: His meticulous attention to detail makes for an excellent final product.
make for.Chinese: 成就了一位成功的企业家

be indicative of sth..definition: If something is indicative of something, it shows or suggests the presence or nature of that thing.
example_sentences: The increase in house prices is indicative of a thriving economy.
be indicative of sth..usage: be indicative of a strong market

hit on sth..definition: If you hit on something, you discover or think of it, often suddenly or by chance.
example_sentences: After hours of brainstorming, she finally hit on a brilliant idea for the project.
hit on sth..usage: hit on a solution to the problem
hit on sth..Chinese: 忽然找到了解决问题的办法

be fast approaching.definition: If something is fast approaching, it is coming near in time.
example_sentences: With the deadline fast approaching, they had to work overtime to complete the assignment.

come as a shock to sb..definition: If something comes as a shock to someone, it is completely unexpected and surprising to them.
example_sentences: The sudden resignation of the CEO came as a shock to the entire company.
come as a shock to sb..usage: come as a shock to the team

in an instant.definition: If something happens in an instant, it occurs very quickly.
example_sentences: The car disappeared around the corner in an instant.
in an instant.usage: disappear around the corner in an instant

follow suit.definition: If you follow suit, you do the same thing as someone else has just done.
example_sentences: When the first guest started dancing, everyone else followed suit.

picture sth. as sth..definition: If you picture something as something, you imagine or think of it in a particular way.
example_sentences: She always pictured the countryside as a peaceful and idyllic place to live.
picture sth. as sth..usage: picture the democracy as a perfect system
picture sth. as sth..Chinese: 把民主描绘成完美的制度

be suited to sb..definition: If something is suited to someone, it is right or appropriate for them.
example_sentences: This quiet, rural life is really suited to him.
be suited to sb..usage: is suited to the students like him

be on the verge of.definition: If you are on the verge of something, you are about to experience it or do it.
example_sentences: She was on the verge of tears as she heard the news.
be on the verge of.useage: be on the verge of tears

count on.definition: If you count on something or someone, you rely on them to support you or help you.
example_sentences: You can always count on me for a helping hand.
count on.usage: count on the manager for support
count on.Chinese: 指望那个经理提供支持

pose a slight inconvenience.definition: If something poses a slight inconvenience, it causes a small amount of trouble or difficulty.
example_sentences: The road closure will pose a slight inconvenience for local residents.
pose a slight inconvenience.usage: pose a slight inconvenience for the neighbours
pose a slight inconvenience.Chinese: 给邻居带来一点小麻烦

be bound to.definition: If you are bound to do something, it is certain or very likely that you will do it.
example_sentences: With his talent, he is bound to succeed in his career.
be bound to.usage: be bound to lose the game

at all times.definition: If something is required at all times, it means it must be done continuously or always.
example_sentences: Passengers must keep their seatbelts fastened at all times during the flight.
at all times.usage: keep the seatbelt fastened at all times
at all times.Chinese: 保持安全带一直是系好的状态

in the nick of time.definition: If something happens in the nick of time, it happens at the last possible moment before it is too late.
example_sentences: The firefighters arrived in the nick of time to save the building.
in the nick of time.usage: arrive in the nick of time

why exactly.definition: If you ask 'why exactly', you are seeking a precise or specific reason for something.
example_sentences: Why exactly did you decide to move to the countryside?
why exactly.usage: ask why exactly he was late
why exactly.Chinese: 问他究竟为什么迟到了

from the perspective of sb.definition: If you consider something from the perspective of someone, you look at it from their point of view or standpoint.
example_sentences: From the perspective of a teacher, the new policy is very beneficial.
from the perspective of sb.usage: consider the issue from the perspective of the students
from the perspective of sb.Chinese: 从学生的角度考虑这个问题

take shelter from sth..definition: If you take shelter from something, you find a place to protect yourself from it.
example_sentences: We took shelter from the rain under a large oak tree.

lose sth. to sth..definition: If you lose A to B, you decide to give up A in order to attain B.
example_sentences: He lost his free time to his demanding job.
lose sth. to sth..Chinese: 为了工作牺牲周末的时间

happen upon.definition: If you happen upon something, you find or encounter it by chance.
example_sentences: While walking in the park, she happened upon an old friend.
happen upon.Chinese: 偶然发现一本珍贵的书

conspire against sth..definition: If events or circumstances conspire against something, they work together to cause it to fail.
example_sentences: The weather and traffic conspired against our plans for a picnic.
conspire against sth..usage: conspire against the progress of the project

not age well.definition: If something does not age well, it means it becomes less appealing or relevant over time.
example_sentences: The special effects in that old film have not aged well.
not age well.usage: the movie that did not age well

hold up.definition: If a theory holds up, it withstands criticism, evidence, or challenges, and continues to be supported by the available data or reasoning.
example_sentences: Despite new research, his original theory still holds up.
hold up.usage: the theory that holds up to scrutiny

have trouble doing sth..definition: If you have trouble doing something, you find it difficult to do.
example_sentences: She had trouble understanding the complex instructions.
have trouble doing sth..usage: have trouble using the new software

toil away at sth..definition: If you toil away at something, you work very hard and for a long time on it.
example_sentences: He toiled away at his novel for years before it was published.
toil away at sth..usage: toil away at his new book
toil away at sth..Chinese: 花很多时间写他的新书

bare the immense responsibility.definition: If you bare the immense responsibility, you accept and deal with a very large and serious duty or obligation.
example_sentences: As the eldest son, he had to bare the immense responsibility of running the family business.
bare the immense responsibility.usage: bare the immense responsibility of the project
bare the immense responsibility.Chinese: 承担项目里的巨大责任

not a problem.definition: If something is not a problem, it means it is easy to deal with or not an issue.
example_sentences: Don't worry about the extra work; it's not a problem for me.
not a problem.usage: not a problem for him to finish the task
not a problem.Chinese: 对他来说完成任务不是问题

connect to.definition: If a device or system connects to something, it links to it electronically or communicates with it.
example_sentences: My printer won't connect to my laptop anymore.

embark on.definition: If you embark on something, you start a new project or period in your life.
example_sentences: She's about to embark on a journey around the world.

uppercase.definition: Uppercase letters are capital letters used to begin sentences or for names.
example_sentences: Please ensure your password includes at least one uppercase letter.
uppercase.usage: include an uppercase letter in the password
uppercase.Chinese: 密码中包含一个大写字母

through the roof.definition: If prices, figures, or temperatures go through the roof, they increase very quickly to a very high level.
example_sentences: After the announcement, the company's stock prices went through the roof.
through the roof.usage: stock prices that went through the roof in a day

off the charts.definition: If something is off the charts, it is far beyond normal levels or expectations.
example_sentences: The popularity of the new game is off the charts.
off the charts.usage: complain about the costs that are off the charts

go over.definition: If you go over something, you examine, review, or check it.
example_sentences: Let's go over the plans once more to ensure everything is correct.
go over.usage: go over the details of the project
go over.Chinese: 再检查一遍项目的细节

look into.definition: If you look into something, you investigate or examine it closely.
example_sentences: There seems to be a problem with our booking; I'll look into it.
look into.usage: look into the issue with the booking
look into.Chinese: 调查预订时出现的的问题

take care of.definition: If you take care of something, you deal with it or resolve it.
example_sentences: Don't worry about the broken window; I'll take care of it.
take care of.usage: take care of the broken window

the list goes on and on.definition: If you say 'the list goes on and on', you mean that there are many more items or examples than you have mentioned.
example_sentences: She's talented at writing, painting, singing -- the list goes on and on.
the list goes on and on.usage: The list of his achievements goes on and on

drive sales.definition: If something drives sales, it causes an increase in the number of products sold.
example_sentences: The new advertising campaign really helped to drive sales.
drive sales.usage: think of strategies to drive sales

match the competitors.definition: If a company or product matches the competitors, it is as good as or better than other companies or products in the same industry.
example_sentences: We need to improve our technology to match the competitors.
match the competitors.usage: improve the quality of our products to match the competitors
match the competitors.Chinese: 提高我们产品质量以赶上竞争对手

damned if you do, and damned if you don'.definition: If you are damned if you do and damned if you don't, you will be criticized no matter what action you take.
example_sentences: He felt like he was damned if he did, and damned if he didn't, so he decided to follow his heart.
damned if you do, and damned if you don'.usage: feel like he was damned if he did, and damned if he didn't
damned if you do, and damned if you don'.Chinese: 感觉不管做还是不做都会受到批评

in the market.definition: If you are in the market, you are actively buying or selling in a particular industry.
example_sentences: With the new product launch, we are now in the market for high-end headphones.
in the market.usage: in the market for electronic vehicles
in the market.Chinese: 在市场上销售电动汽车

will never fly.definition: If you say an idea or plan will never fly, you mean it will never be successful.
example_sentences: His idea for a solar-powered toaster will never fly.
will never fly.usage: the plan that will never fly

be here any minute.definition: If someone is going to be here any minute, they will arrive very soon.
example_sentences: The guests will be here any minute, so we need to finish setting the table.
be here any minute.usage: the guests who will be here any minute

a brilliant idea.definition: A brilliant idea is an exceptionally clever or innovative thought or plan.
example_sentences: She had a brilliant idea to host a charity bake sale.
a brilliant idea.usage: have a brilliant idea for the project
a brilliant idea.Chinese: 为项目想出一个好主意

kick sb. out.definition: If you kick someone out, you force them to leave a place.
example_sentences: The landlord decided to kick him out for not paying the rent.
kick sb. out.usage: kick him out of the house because he didn't pay the rent
kick sb. out.Chinese: 因为他没交房租把他赶出房子

creep sb. out.definition: If something creeps someone out, it makes them feel uneasy or frightened.
example_sentences: The old abandoned house really creeps me out.
creep sb. out.usage: the abandoned house that creeps me out
creep sb. out.Chinese: 让我感到毛骨悚然的荒废的房子

scare the heck out of sb..definition: If something scares the heck out of someone, it frightens them very much.
example_sentences: The horror film scared the heck out of me.
scare the heck out of sb..usage: the horror film that scared the heck out of me
scare the heck out of sb..Chinese: 把我吓得要命的恐怖电影

fill sb. in.definition: If you fill someone in, you give them all the details about something.
example_sentences: Can you fill me in on what happened at the meeting yesterday?
fill sb. in.usage: ask her to fill me in on the details

a house warming gift.definition: A house warming gift is a present given to someone who has just moved into a new home.
example_sentences: We brought a bottle of wine as a house warming gift for our new neighbours.
a house warming gift.usage: bring a house warming gift for the new neighbours
a house warming gift.Chinese: 给新邻居带了一个礼物

I don't know if you've heard.definition: If you say 'I don't know if you've heard', you are about to share some news or information that the listener might not be aware of.
example_sentences: I don't know if you've heard, but Jane is getting married next month.
I don't know if you've heard.usage: I don't know if you've heard, but Jane is getting married next month
I don't know if you've heard.Chinese: 我不知道你有没有听说，Jane下个月要结婚了

you'll never guess.definition: If you say 'you'll never guess', you are about to reveal surprising or unexpected information.
example_sentences: You'll never guess who I ran into at the supermarket today!
you'll never guess.usage: You'll never guess who I ran into at the supermarket today
you'll never guess.Chinese: 你肯定猜不到我今天在超市里碰到了谁

such a mess.definition: If you describe something as 'such a mess', you mean it is very untidy or disorganised.
example_sentences: After the party, the living room was such a mess.
such a mess.usage: complains that the living room is such a mess

chores.definition: Chores are routine tasks or duties, especially those related to household maintenance.
example_sentences: Every Saturday morning, we all help with the household chores.

set the table.definition: If you set the table, you arrange the cutlery, plates, and glasses in preparation for a meal.
example_sentences: Could you please set the table for dinner?

tidy up.definition: If you tidy up, you make a place neat and orderly.
example_sentences: Let's tidy up the living room before our guests arrive.

spotless.definition: If something is spotless, it is completely clean and free from dirt or stains.
example_sentences: She keeps her kitchen absolutely spotless.

in the middle of sth..definition: If you are in the middle of something, you are busy doing it at the moment.
example_sentences: I'm in the middle of cooking dinner, can I call you back later?
in the middle of sth..usage: in the middle of cooking dinner

hoover the house.definition: If you hoover the house, you clean the floors using a vacuum cleaner.
example_sentences: I need to hoover the house before the guests arrive.
hoover the house.usage: hoover the house before the guests arrive
hoover the house.Chinese: 在客人到来之前用吸尘器打扫房子

on the blink.definition: If something is on the blink, it is not working properly.
example_sentences: The television is on the blink again, so we might need to call the repairman.
on the blink.usage: the television that is on the blink

ally oneself with.definition: If you ally yourself with someone or something, you give your support to them.
example_sentences: During the debate, she decided to ally herself with the environmentalists to promote green policies.

go on the rampage.definition: If a group of people go on the rampage, they rush about in a wild or violent way, causing damage or destruction.
example_sentences: After their team lost the match, some fans went on the rampage, breaking shop windows and overturning cars.
go on the rampage.usage: go on the rampage after the match

have pretensions to sth..definition: If someone has pretensions to something, they claim to have it or to be able to do it, even though this is not true.
example_sentences: He has pretensions to being a gourmet chef, but his cooking is quite basic.
have pretensions to sth..usage: have pretensions to be a gourmet chef

bide one's time.definition: If you bide your time, you wait quietly for a good opportunity before doing something.
example_sentences: She decided to bide her time and wait for the perfect moment to present her proposal.
bide one's time.usage: bide his time and wait for the right moment to buy the stock
bide one's time.Chinese: 等待合适的时机买股票

the length and breadth of sth..definition: If you say that someone does something or something happens throughout or across the length and breadth of a place, you are emphasizing that it happens everywhere in that place.
example_sentences: The Queen's Jubilee was celebrated throughout the length and breadth of the United Kingdom.
the length and breadth of sth..usage: travel the length and breadth of the country

make a nuisance of oneself.definition: If someone makes a nuisance of themselves, they are behaving in an annoying way.
example_sentences: The children made a nuisance of themselves by running around the restaurant and disturbing other diners.
make a nuisance of oneself.usage: make a nuisance of themselves by running around the restaurant
make a nuisance of oneself.Chinese: 在餐厅里到处跑，让人讨厌

superficial injury.definition: A superficial injury is not very serious and only affects the surface of your body.
example_sentences: He sustained a superficial injury during the football match, which only required a plaster.
superficial injury.usage: have a superficial injury after the football match
superficial injury.Chinese: 在足球比赛后受了轻伤

multiple stores.definition: A multiple store is a shop with a lot of branches in different towns.
example_sentences: Marks & Spencer is a well-known multiple store with locations across the UK.

see the error in one's ways.definition: If someone sees the error in their ways, they realise that their past behaviour or actions were wrong.
example_sentences: After a long conversation with his mentor, he finally saw the error in his ways and decided to apologise.
see the error in one's ways.usage: see the error in his ways and apologise
see the error in one's ways.Chinese: 认识到自己的错误并道歉

to the utmost.definition: If you do something to the utmost, you do it to the greatest possible extent or degree.
example_sentences: She worked to the utmost to ensure the success of the charity event.
to the utmost.usage: work to the utmost to ensure the success of the event
to the utmost.Chinese: 尽最大努力确保活动的成功

in error.definition: If something is done in error, it is done mistakenly or by accident.
example_sentences: The letter was sent to the wrong address in error.
in error.usage: the bill that is written in error

a twist in sth..definition: A twist in something is an unexpected and significant development.
example_sentences: The novel's plot had a surprising twist in the final chapter that left readers in awe.
a twist in sth..usage: don't expect the twist in the plot

prostrate.definition: If someone is prostrate, they are so distressed or affected by a very bad experience that they are unable to do anything at all.
example_sentences: He was prostrate with grief after hearing the tragic news.
prostrate.usage: be prostrate with grief after hearing the news

a bulge in sth..definition: If there is a bulge in something, there is a sudden large increase in it.
example_sentences: There was a noticeable bulge in the population after the war.
a bulge in sth..usage: a bulge in the population after the war

exact a high price.definition: If something exacts a high price, it has a bad effect on a person or situation.
example_sentences: The long hours at work exacted a high price on his health.
exact a high price.usage: the mistake that exacted a high price
exact a high price.Chinese: 事后造成严重后果的错误

at one's beck and call.definition: If one person is at another's beck and call, they have to be constantly available and ready to do whatever is asked, and this often seems unfair or undesirable.
example_sentences: She felt like she was at her boss's beck and call, always having to respond to his demands.
at one's beck and call.usage: at his boss's beck and call

exact a revenge on sb..definition: If someone exacts revenge on a person, they have their revenge on them.
example_sentences: He vowed to exact revenge on those who had wronged him.
exact a revenge on sb..usage: exact revenge on his manager for firing him

a dispensation from sth..definition: If someone is given a dispensation from a rule or obligation, they are allowed not to follow it or carry it out.
example_sentences: The student received a dispensation from the final exam due to exceptional circumstances.
a dispensation from sth..usage: a dispensation from the final exam

in all likelihood.definition: If you say that something will happen in all likelihood, you mean that it will probably happen.
example_sentences: In all likelihood, the match will be postponed due to the heavy rain.
in all likelihood.usage: the event that will be postponed in all likelihood

arrogate sth. to oneself.definition: If someone arrogates to themselves something such as a responsibility or privilege, they claim or take it even though they have no right to do so.
example_sentences: He arrogated to himself the authority to make decisions without consulting the committee.
arrogate sth. to oneself.usage: arrogate to himself the authority to make decisions

in rotation.definition: If people do something in rotation, they take turns to do it.
example_sentences: The nurses worked in rotation to ensure that someone was always on duty.
in rotation.usage: work in rotation to keep the room clean

in debt.definition: If someone is in debt, it means they owe money to another person or institution.
example_sentences: After renovating his flat, John found himself in debt to the bank for quite a sum.
in debt.usage: the entropreneur who is deep in debt

broke.definition: If someone is broke, it means they have no money at all.
example_sentences: Having spent his last quid on a pint, Tom was completely broke until payday.
broke.usage: find out that his husband is broke

hit sb. pretty hard.definition: If something hits someone pretty hard, it means it affects them very negatively or severely.
example_sentences: The closure of the local factory hit the village pretty hard, leaving many unemployed.
hit sb. pretty hard.usage: the news that hit the family pretty hard
hit sb. pretty hard.Chinese: 让全家感到很沮丧的消息

tuition.definition: Tuition is the money paid for instruction, especially at a university or college.
example_sentences: Despite the high tuition fees, Oxbridge remains a popular choice for many British students.
tuition.usage: pay the tuition fees for the course

take out a loan.definition: If you take out a loan, it means you borrow money from a bank or other financial institution.
example_sentences: Sarah had to take out a loan to cover the deposit on her new flat in London.
take out a loan.usage: take out a loan to buy the new flat

trouble sb..definition: If you trouble someone, it means you inconvenience them by asking for help or assistance.
example_sentences: Might I trouble you for a spot of tea, if it's not too much bother?
trouble sb..usage: ask him if I can trouble him for a lift

on top of all that.definition: If something happens on top of all that, it means it occurs in addition to other things, usually unpleasant ones.
example_sentences: The train was delayed, it started raining, and on top of all that, I lost my umbrella.
on top of all that.usage: complain about the delay, the rain, and on top of all that, losing the umbrella
on top of all that.Chinese: 抱怨火车晚点，下雨，还丢了伞

knock over sth..definition: If you knock over something, it means you accidentally hit it, causing it to fall.
example_sentences: In his rush to catch the bus, James knocked over the vase of flowers on the hall table.

knock over sb..definition: If you knock over someone, it means you accidentally collide with them, causing them to fall.
example_sentences: The excited Labrador knocked over the postman as he came through the garden gate.

place.definition: Someone's place is their home or residence.
example_sentences: After the pub quiz, we all went back to Mary's place for a nightcap.
place.usage: come over to my place for dinner

feel terrible.definition: If you feel terrible, it means you experience strong feelings of guilt, regret, or physical discomfort.
example_sentences: I feel terrible about forgetting Granny's birthday; I must send her a card straightaway.
feel terrible.usage: feel terrible about forgetting the birthday
feel terrible.Chinese: 因为忘记生日而感到内疚

don't mean to.definition: If you say you don't mean to do something, it indicates that your action was unintentional.
example_sentences: I don't mean to be a bother, but could you possibly turn down the wireless a tad?

a tilt at sth..definition: A tilt at something is an attempt or effort to achieve or accomplish it.
example_sentences: After years of dreaming, Nigel finally decided to have a tilt at writing his first novel.
a tilt at sth..usage: have a tilt at writing the first novel

shudder to think.definition: If you shudder to think about something, you feel very worried or frightened when you consider it.
example_sentences: I shudder to think what might have happened if we hadn't installed a smoke alarm in the flat.
shudder to think.usage: shudder to think about the consequences

take a plunge.definition: If you take a plunge, you decide to do something important or risky after thinking about it for a long time.
example_sentences: After years of hesitation, Nigel finally took the plunge and proposed to his long-time girlfriend during afternoon tea.
take a plunge.usage: take the plunge and invest in the company

send a shudder through sth..definition: If something sends a shudder through a group of people, it makes them feel very frightened or worried.
example_sentences: The announcement of potential redundancies sent a shudder through the entire workforce at the biscuit factory.
send a shudder through sth..usage: send a shudder through the cabinet

make a left.definition: When you make a left while driving, you turn left.
example_sentences: To get to the local pub, make a left at the roundabout and continue straight for about half a mile.
make a left.usage: make a left at the next junction

step on it.definition: When you tell someone to step on it when they are driving, you are telling them to drive faster.
example_sentences: We're late for the cricket match! Step on it, would you?
step on it.usage: step on it to get to the match on time
step on it.Chinese: 车开快点以便准时到达比赛

have a fit.definition: If someone has a fit, they become very angry or upset.
example_sentences: Mum will have a fit if she sees the state of the kitchen after our attempt at making Yorkshire puddings.
have a fit.usage: have a fit when she sees the mess in the kitchen
have a fit.Chinese: 看到厨房一片狼藉以后大发雷霆

cut through.definition: If you cut through a place, you go through it to get to another place quickly.
example_sentences: Let's cut through the park to reach the high street; it'll save us a good five minutes.

short cut.definition: If you take a short cut, you go a quicker way than the usual way.
example_sentences: I know a brilliant short cut to avoid the queue on the motorway; it goes past a lovely old manor house.
short cut.usage: take a short cut to avoid the traffic

run a red light.definition: If you run a red light, you drive through a red traffic light.
example_sentences: The lorry driver nearly ran a red light at the busy junction, causing pedestrians to leap back onto the pavement.
run a red light.usage: run a red light at the junction

are you nuts.definition: If you say to someone 'Are you nuts?' you are asking them if they are crazy.
example_sentences: Are you nuts? You can't wear trainers to a formal garden party at Buckingham Palace!
are you nuts.usage: can't help but yell 'Are you nuts?'

side street.definition: A side street is a small street that is connected to a main street.
example_sentences: We found a charming little tea shop tucked away in a side street off the bustling high street.

take the street.definition: If you take the street, you walk or drive along the street.
example_sentences: To get to the local chippy, take the street on your left and continue past the old red telephone box.
take the street.usage: take the street and turn left
take the street.Chinese: 沿着这条路走然后左转

road rage.definition: If you have road rage, you become very angry at other drivers when you are driving.
example_sentences: The gentleman in the Aston Martin displayed alarming road rage when another driver failed to indicate at the mini-roundabout.
road rage.Chinese: 一个劲对别的司机发火

back up.definition: If you back up, you drive backwards.
example_sentences: Could you please back up a bit? I'm having trouble getting out of this tight parking space near the village green.
back up.usage: back up to get out of the parking space

groom.definition: A groom is the man who is getting married in a wedding ceremony.
example_sentences: The groom nervously adjusted his bow tie as he waited for his bride at the altar.

bride.definition: A bride is the woman who is getting married in a wedding ceremony.
example_sentences: The bride looked radiant as she walked down the aisle in her white gown.

it's about time.definition: When you say it's about time, you mean that something should have happened a long time ago.
example_sentences: It's about time the council fixed those potholes on the high street!
it's about time.usage: say it's about time to tidy up the garden
it's about time.Chinese: 表示是时候整理花园了

aisle.definition: An aisle is a long narrow gap that people walk along between rows of seats in a public building such as a church or theatre.
example_sentences: The ushers guided guests to their seats along the flower-decorated aisle.

bridesmaid.definition: A bridesmaid is a female friend or relative who helps the bride at a wedding.
example_sentences: Sarah chose her sister as her chief bridesmaid for the big day.
bridesmaid.usage: ask her sister to be the bridesmaid

flower girl.definition: A flower girl is a girl at a wedding that throws flower petals down the aisle
example_sentences: Little Emily, the flower girl, scattered rose petals as she walked ahead of the bride.
flower girl.usage: ask Emily to be the flower girl

ring bearer.definition: A ring bearer is a boy at a wedding that holds the wedding rings.
example_sentences: The young ring bearer carefully carried the cushion with the rings down the aisle.
ring bearer.usage: ask the nephew to be the ring bearer

gorgeous.definition: If you say that something is gorgeous, you mean that it is very beautiful or attractive.
example_sentences: The bride's dress was absolutely gorgeous, with intricate lace detailing.
gorgeous.usage: a gorgeous hall for the wedding

groomsman.definition: A groomsman is a male friend or relative who helps the groom on the wedding day.
example_sentences: James asked his university flatmates to be his groomsmen at the wedding.
groomsman.usage: invite his best friend to be the groomsmen
groomsman.Chinese: 邀请他最好的朋友做伴郎

go bankrupt.definition: If a person or company goes bankrupt, they are unable to pay their debts and are legally declared to be in financial ruin.
example_sentences: The local pub went bankrupt after struggling through the economic downturn.
go bankrupt.usage: go bankrupt after being bailed out

bail out.definition: If a person or company is bailed out, they receive help to escape a difficult situation, often financial.
example_sentences: The government had to bail out several banks during the financial crisis, much to the chagrin of many taxpayers.
bail out.usage: bail out the company after the financial crisis
bail out.Chinese: 在金融危机后救助公司

injustice.definition: Injustice is a lack of fairness or equity in a situation.
example_sentences: The inequality in school funding across different boroughs was seen as a glaring injustice by many parents and teachers.

mismanaged.definition: If something is mismanaged, it is handled or organised in an incompetent or improper manner.
example_sentences: The council's mismanaged bin collection schedule left rubbish piling up on the streets for weeks.

have the nerve to.definition: If you say that someone has the nerve to do something, you mean they behave in a way you find remarkably bold or impertinent.
example_sentences: I couldn't believe he had the nerve to ask for a pay rise after turning up late to work every day this week!
have the nerve to.usage: have the nerve to ask for a pay rise

make several millions.definition: If someone makes several millions, they earn a very large amount of money, typically in the millions of pounds.
example_sentences: The footballer was rumoured to make several millions each year from his lucrative endorsement deals.
make several millions.usage: make several millions from the endorsement deals
make several millions.Chinese: 通过代言合同赚取数百万

placard.definition: A placard is a large sign or notice, often carried during public demonstrations or displayed in prominent places.
example_sentences: The striking workers marched through the city centre, holding placards that demanded better working conditions.
placard.usage: hold a placard that demands better working conditions
placard.Chinese: 举着要求更好工作条件的标语牌

rally.definition: A rally is a large public gathering held to show support for a cause or political party.
example_sentences: Thousands attended the rally in Trafalgar Square to protest against the proposed changes to the NHS.
rally.usage: attend the rally to support the candidate

proponent.definition: A proponent is a person who advocates for or supports a particular idea, policy, or course of action.
example_sentences: As a staunch proponent of free school meals, the MP argued passionately for the programme's expansion in Parliament.
proponent.usage: a proponent of the free school meals
proponent.Chinese: 免费学校午餐的支持者

stick one's head out of the window.definition: If you stick your head out of a window, you put your head outside through an open window.
example_sentences: As the steam train pulled into the station, eager children stuck their heads out of the windows to catch a glimpse of the platform.
stick one's head out of the window.usage: stick his head out of the window and wave to the crowd
stick one's head out of the window.Chinese: 把头伸出窗外向人群挥手

PA announcement.definition: A PA announcement is a message broadcast over a public address system in a public place.
example_sentences: The PA announcement at Tesco reminded shoppers that the store would be closing in fifteen minutes.
PA announcement.usage: pay attention to the PA announcement

across from.definition: If something is across from another thing, it is on the opposite side of a space or street.
example_sentences: The local pub is across from the village green, making it a popular spot for a pint after a game of cricket.
across from.usage: the pub across from the church

in the proximity of.definition: If something is in the proximity of a place, it is near or close to that location.
example_sentences: The bed and breakfast was in the proximity of Stonehenge, allowing guests to easily visit the ancient monument.
in the proximity of.usage: the hotel in the proximity of the airport

watch sth..definition: If you watch something, you look after or keep an eye on it, often to prevent theft or damage.
example_sentences: Could you watch my shopping trolley while I pop to the loo?
watch sth..usage: watch the bags while she goes to the loo

the exploit of sb..definition: An exploit is a daring or adventurous act or feat, often involving bravery or skill.
example_sentences: The exploits of Sir Francis Drake, including his circumnavigation of the globe, are still celebrated in British history.

cash in the empties.definition: When you cash in the empties, you return empty bottles or cans to a shop in order to get money back.
example_sentences: After the weekend party, I cashed in the empties and used the money to buy some crisps.
cash in the empties.usage: forget to cash in the empties

pay a deposit.definition: When you pay a deposit, you pay a sum of money as a guarantee that you will return something in good condition.
example_sentences: I had to pay a deposit when I rented the flat in London.
pay a deposit.usage: pay a deposit for the flat

get down to brass tacks.definition: When you get down to brass tacks, you start talking about the most important or basic facts of a situation.
example_sentences: Let's get down to brass tacks and discuss the menu for the Queen's Jubilee celebration.
get down to brass tacks.usage: get down to brass tacks and talk about the plan for the party
get down to brass tacks.Chinese: 回到正题讨论派对的计划

defy sb. to do sth..definition: When you defy someone to do something, you challenge them to do it.
example_sentences: He defied his mates to finish the Yorkshire pudding challenge.
defy sb. to do sth..usage: defy him to eat the whole cake
defy sb. to do sth..Chinese: 赌他不能吃完整个蛋糕

a deluge of sth..definition: A deluge of something is a large amount of it arriving at the same time.
example_sentences: After the Wimbledon match, we received a deluge of emails from excited fans.

at room temperature.definition: If something is at room temperature, its temperature is neither hot nor cold.
example_sentences: The scones are best served at room temperature with a dollop of clotted cream.
at room temperature.usage: make the steak at room temperature

hurl abuse at sb..definition: When you hurl abuse at someone, you shout insults at them.
example_sentences: The football fans began to hurl abuse at the referee after the controversial call.

be hounded out of a job.definition: If someone is hounded out of a job, they are forced to leave it because people make it impossible for them to stay.
example_sentences: The MP was hounded out of his job following the scandal.
be hounded out of a job.usage: be hounded out of the job after the scandal

a tyranny of sth..definition: A tyranny of something is a situation in which there is too much of it, usually something unpleasant.
example_sentences: The tyranny of rain during the summer festival was disheartening.
a tyranny of sth..usage: deal with a tyranny of inquires

defy all comprehension.definition: If something defies all comprehension, it is so strange or difficult that it is impossible to understand.
example_sentences: The complex rules of cricket defy all comprehension for some.

one's spirits soar.definition: If someone's spirits soar, they suddenly feel very happy or excited.
example_sentences: His spirits soared when he saw the fish and chips sign on the seaside.
one's spirits soar.usage: calm down after seeing his son's spirits soar
one's spirits soar.Chinese: 看到儿子非常高兴以后才冷静下来

impute sth. to sb..definition: If you impute something to someone, you say that they are responsible for it.
example_sentences: The report imputed the failure to the project manager.
impute sth. to sb..usage: impute the failure to the project manager
impute sth. to sb..Chinese: 把失败归咎于项目经理

refund sb. with sth..definition: If a seller refunds you with something, you obtain that thing as a refund.
example_sentences: The shop agreed to refund me with a store voucher for the faulty item.
refund sb. with sth..usage: refund the customer with a store voucher
refund sb. with sth..Chinese: 用商店礼券退款给顾客

be secretive about sth..definition: If someone is secretive about something, they do not want to talk about it or share information about it.
example_sentences: She was secretive about her recipe for the perfect Victoria sponge cake.

out of all proportion to sth..definition: If you think A is out of all proportion to B, you think A is much larger or smaller than it should be in relation to B.
example_sentences: The queue for the royal wedding was out of all proportion to the event's capacity.
out of all proportion to sth..usage: out of all proportion to what is needed

to the accompaniment of.definition: When something happens to the accompaniment of something else, it happens at the same time as the other thing.
example_sentences: The Queen's Guard marched to the accompaniment of a traditional military band.
to the accompaniment of.usage: go home to the accompaniment of the rain

in quantity.definition: Things that are produced in quantity are produced in large numbers.
example_sentences: The bakery bakes scones in quantity for the afternoon tea at Buckingham Palace.
in quantity.usage: produce the new product in quantity

be a disgrace.definition: If you say that something is a disgrace, you are emphasising that it is very bad or wrong, and that you find it completely unacceptable.
example_sentences: It's a disgrace that some people still litter in our beautiful national parks.
be a disgrace.usage: agree that the business is indeed a disgrace
be a disgrace.Chinese: 同意这家公司的确让人无法接受

pass the baton to sb..definition: If you pass the baton to someone, you give them responsibility for something that you have been doing.
example_sentences: The headmaster passed the baton to the deputy head after 30 years of service.
pass the baton to sb..usage: pass the baton to the son
pass the baton to sb..Chinese: 把公司经营权传给儿子

leave a scar on sb..definition: If an event or experience leaves a scar on someone, it has a lasting negative effect on them.
example_sentences: The loss of his pet dog left a scar on the young boy, making him fearful of forming attachments.
leave a scar on sb..usage: leave a scar on the young boy

preferential treatment.definition: If you get preferential treatment, you are treated better than other people in the same situation.
example_sentences: Members of Parliament receive preferential treatment when booking tours of the Houses of Parliament.

a hoard of.definition: A hoard of things is a large amount of them that someone has kept in a secret place.
example_sentences: The antique dealer found a hoard of vintage postage stamps in the attic of an old manor house.

a specimen of.definition: A specimen of something is an example of it that shows what it is like.
example_sentences: The museum displayed a specimen of the first computer ever built, showcasing its size and complexity.
a specimen of.usage: display a specimen of the first computer
a specimen of.Chinese: 展示第一台计算机的样品

a literal person.definition: If you describe someone as a literal person, you mean that they interpret words in their exact and most basic sense.
example_sentences: John is a literal person, so when you tell him to 'break a leg', he might get confused and worry about actual physical harm.
a literal person.usage: turn out to be a literal person
a literal person.Chinese: 原来是个不懂得变通的人

exact.definition: If you exact something such as a promise or a punishment, you demand that it be done or given.
example_sentences: The headmaster exacted a written apology from the mischievous pupil.
exact.Chinese: 要求他的丈夫兑现承诺

a flame.definition: A flame is an email message that is angry, critical, or accusatory in tone.
example_sentences: After posting a controversial opinion online, my inbox was flooded with flames from disgruntled readers.
a flame.usage: receive a flame from the reader
a flame.Chinese: 收到一封来自读者的用来泄愤的邮件

radio network.definition: A radio network is a company or group of companies that broadcasts radio throughout an area.
example_sentences: The BBC is a well-known radio network that reaches listeners across the United Kingdom.

network with sb..definition: If you network with people, you talk to them and exchange information with them, especially in order to get work or to make business contacts.
example_sentences: At the charity gala, I had the opportunity to network with several influential members of Parliament.
network with sb..usage: network with the influential members of Parliament
network with sb..Chinese: 与有影响力的议员建立联系

be specific about sth..definition: If you are specific about something, you give details or a clear description of it.
example_sentences: When ordering tea at a café, it's best to be specific about how you like it prepared.

walk down the aisle.definition: If you walk down the aisle, you get married.
example_sentences: The bride walked down the aisle of Westminster Abbey, her dress trailing behind her.
walk down the aisle.usage: be about to walk down the aisle

be groomed for sth..definition: If you are groomed for a particular job or position, someone prepares you for it by teaching you the necessary skills and giving you the necessary experience.
example_sentences: As the eldest son of the Duke, he was groomed for a life of royal duties from an early age.
be groomed for sth..usage: be groomed for the higher position

walk past sth..definition: If you walk past a place, you walk near it or next to it without stopping.
example_sentences: I often walk past Buckingham Palace on my way to work in central London.

move by sb..definition: If a vehicle moves by someone, it passes them.
example_sentences: The red double-decker bus moved by me as I waited at the zebra crossing.

be a mouthful.definition: If a word is a mouthful, it is long and difficult to say.
example_sentences: The name of that Welsh village is certainly a mouthful!
be a mouthful.usage: find the Asian names always a mouthful
be a mouthful.Chinese: 总觉得亚洲名字很难念对

browse the aisles.definition: If you browse the aisles when you are shopping, you walk slowly up and down the aisles looking at things.
example_sentences: I love to browse the aisles of Harrods, even if I can't afford to buy anything.
browse the aisles.usage: browse the aisles of the supermarket

a walk in the park.definition: If you describe something as a walk in the park, you mean that it is very easy to do.
example_sentences: Compared to last year's exam, this one was a walk in the park.
a walk in the park.usage: only to find out that the interview was a walk in the park

plump for sth..definition: If you plump for something, you choose it from a number of possibilities.
example_sentences: After much deliberation over the menu, I finally plumped for the traditional fish and chips.

beyond redemption.definition: If you say that someone or something is beyond redemption, you mean that they are so bad that they cannot be helped or improved in any way.
example_sentences: After the politician's third scandal, many voters considered him beyond redemption and called for his resignation.
beyond redemption.Chinese: 认为这个学生无药可救

be reminiscent of sth..definition: If you say that A is reminiscent of B, you mean that A reminds you of B because of some similarity between them.
example_sentences: The quaint village pub was reminiscent of those found in Agatha Christie novels.
be reminiscent of sth..usage: be reminiscent of the old days

appoint.definition: If you appoint someone to a job or official position, you formally choose them for it.
example_sentences: The Queen appointed a new Prime Minister following the general election.

step out of.definition: If you step out of a place, you leave it.
example_sentences: As I stepped out of the tube station, I was greeted by the bustling streets of London.
step out of.usage: step out of the tube station

step in.definition: If you step in a place, you enter it.
example_sentences: Please step in the drawing room; I'll fetch us some tea.

get a load of sth..definition: If you ask someone to get a load of something, you are asking them to look at it or listen to it.
example_sentences: Get a load of that chap's bowler hat; it's absolutely enormous!
get a load of sth..usage: come and get a load of the new car

pay heed to sth..definition: If you pay heed to someone or something, you pay attention to them and consider carefully what they say.
example_sentences: The council would do well to pay heed to the residents' concerns about the new motorway.

take one's temperature.definition: If you take someone's temperature, you measure it using a thermometer in order to find out if they have a fever.
example_sentences: The school nurse took Johnny's temperature to see if he needed to be sent home.

ingratiate oneself with sb..definition: If you ingratiate yourself with someone, you do things to try and make them like you.
example_sentences: The new employee attempted to ingratiate himself with the manager by offering to work overtime.

be blasé about sth..definition: If you are blasé about something, you are not impressed, excited, or worried about it because you have seen or experienced it many times before.
example_sentences: Having lived in central London for years, Sarah was rather blasé about seeing celebrities in the street.
be blasé about sth..usage: be blasé about the new generation of iPhones
be blasé about sth..Chinese: 对新一代的iPhone不感到新奇

one's patter about sth..definition: Someone's patter about something is a series of things that they say quickly and easily, usually in order to entertain people or to persuade them to buy something.
example_sentences: The market stallholder's patter about his wares was so convincing that many people couldn't resist buying.
one's patter about sth..usage: have to stand his patter about the new product
one's patter about sth..Chinese: 不得不忍受听他对新产品不停地吹嘘

a coup.definition: A coup is an achievement which is thought to be especially good because it is very difficult.
example_sentences: Winning the contract with the prestigious client was a real coup for the small firm.
a coup.usage: be a real coup for the small firm
a coup.Chinese: 对小公司来说是一大成功

literature from someone.definition: The literature from someone is the written information from people who want to sell you something or give you advice.
example_sentences: The sales representative handed out some literature about the new product range to all the attendees.
We expect to receive the literature from the company about the new software.
literature from someone.usage: hand out the literature from the company
literature from someone.Chinese: 分发关于这家公司的宣传资料

in the belief.definition: If you do something in the belief that something is true, you do it because you think it is true.
example_sentences: She accepted the job offer in the belief that it would lead to better career prospects.
in the belief.usage: come to the party in the belief that it would be fun
in the belief.Chinese: 来参加派对，希望这个派对会很有趣

networked.definition: When a television or radio programme is networked, it is broadcast simultaneously by all the television or radio stations in a country.
example_sentences: The Queen's Christmas message is always networked across all major television channels in the UK.
networked.usage: the Queen's Christmas message that has been networked across all major television channels
networked.Chinese: 英国所有主要电视台都已经播出的女王圣诞致辞

a stroke of luck.definition: A stroke of luck or good fortune is something lucky that happens to you.
example_sentences: Finding a parking space right outside the theatre was a real stroke of luck on a busy Saturday night.
a stroke of luck.usage: gain a lot of money from the stock market with a stroke of luck
a stroke of luck.Chinese: 凭运气在股市赚了一大笔钱

of necessity.definition: If you say that something is of necessity the case, you mean that it is the case because nothing else is possible or practical in the circumstances.
example_sentences: Negotiations between the two sides are of necessity indirect.
of necessity.usage: the negotiations that are of necessity discreet

tease.definition: If you tease someone, you make fun of them in an unkind way or say things to annoy or embarrass them.
example_sentences: He liked to tease his younger sister about her obsession with pop music.
tease.usage: tease the colleague about his new haircut

be explicit about sth..definition: If you are explicit about something, you speak about it very openly and clearly.
example_sentences: The terms of the agreement were made explicit during the meeting to avoid any misunderstandings.

be obsequious to sb..definition: If you say A is obsequious to B, you are criticising A because they are too eager to help or agree with B, who is more important than them.
example_sentences: His obsequious behaviour towards his boss was noticeable and somewhat off-putting to his colleagues.

navigate the crowd.definition: If you navigate the crowd, you move carefully through a large group of people.
example_sentences: I had to navigate the crowd at Piccadilly Circus to catch my bus on time.
navigate the crowd.usage: nevigate the crowd at the train station

be all ears.definition: If you are all ears, you are very eager to hear what someone has to say.
example_sentences: Go on, tell me about your holiday in Cornwall. I'm all ears!
be all ears.usage: be all ears about the new project
be all ears.Chinese: 非常想听听关于新项目的事

desk worker.definition: A desk worker is someone who performs their job duties primarily at a desk in an office.
example_sentences: As a desk worker, Sarah finds it important to take regular breaks to stretch her legs.
desk worker.Chinese: 一个无聊的办公室职员

come under fire.definition: If someone comes under fire, they are criticised or attacked verbally.
example_sentences: The Prime Minister came under fire for his handling of the NHS crisis.
come under fire.usage: come under fire for the decision

mix and match.definition: If someone mixes and matches, they combine different items or styles in a creative or unconventional way.
example_sentences: For a smart casual look, you can mix and match your blazer with different trousers.

walk back.definition: If someone walks back a statement, they retract or modify it to lessen its impact or meaning.
example_sentences: The Minister had to walk back his comments after they caused a public outcry.

dial back.definition: If someone dials back a situation, they attempt to reduce its intensity or seriousness.
example_sentences: Let's dial back the tension and discuss this over a nice cup of tea, shall we?

crowd surge.definition: A crowd surge is a sudden, forceful movement of a large group of people in a particular direction.
example_sentences: There was a dangerous crowd surge at the football match when the winning goal was scored.
crowd surge.usage: a crowd surge at the concert
crowd surge.Chinese: 演唱会时暴增的人流量

wrap one's mind around.definition: If you wrap your mind around something, you make an effort to understand or accept a complex or difficult concept.
example_sentences: I'm struggling to wrap my mind around the new tax regulations.
wrap one's mind around.usage: wrap his mind around the difficult concept

pile up.definition: If things pile up, they accumulate or increase in quantity, often causing stress or inconvenience.
example_sentences: The dirty dishes have piled up in the sink; it's time for a good wash-up.
pile up.usage: dirty dishes that have piled up over the weekend

sound the alarm.definition: If you sound the alarm, you warn people about a dangerous or problematic situation.
example_sentences: The neighbourhood watch sounded the alarm about the increase in local burglaries.
sound the alarm.usage: sound the alarm about the increasing crime rate

aside from.definition: If you say 'aside from', you are introducing a statement that is not directly related to what you have just said.
example_sentences: Aside from the occasional drizzle, the weather in Brighton was quite pleasant for our seaside holiday.
aside from.usage: buy some chocolate aside from the groceries
aside from.Chinese: 除了买杂货外还买了巧克力

set up the internet service.definition: If someone sets up the internet service, they arrange for the internet to be connected and made operational in a particular place.
example_sentences: We asked the local broadband provider to set up the internet service in our new flat before we moved in.
set up the internet service.usage: set up the internet service in the new flat
set up the internet service.Chinese: 在新公寓安装网络服务

telecom company.definition: A telecom company is an organisation that provides telecommunications services such as telephone and internet connections.
example_sentences: British Telecom, commonly known as BT, is one of the largest telecom companies in the UK.

internet technician.definition: An internet technician is a professional who installs, maintains, and repairs internet connections and related equipment.
example_sentences: When our Wi-Fi kept dropping out, we called an internet technician from Virgin Media to sort out the problem.
internet technician.usage: call an internet technician to fix the Wi-Fi

hit the spot.definition: If you say that something hits the spot, you mean that it is exactly what is needed or wanted at a particular time.
example_sentences: After a long day of sightseeing in London, a pint of ale at the local pub really hit the spot.
hit the spot.usage: some ice creame that would hit the spot
hit the spot.Chinese: 一些现在正好想吃的冰淇淋

break a sweat.definition: If you break a sweat, you begin to perspire due to physical exertion or stress.
example_sentences: Despite the challenging hike up Snowdon, our experienced guide didn't even break a sweat.
break a sweat.usage: not even break a sweat during the marathon
break a sweat.Chinese: 马拉松比赛中甚至没有出一滴汗

delivery person.definition: A delivery person is someone whose job is to transport and deliver goods to people's homes or places of work.
example_sentences: The delivery person from Tesco brought our weekly shop right to our doorstep.

bummer.definition: If you say that something is a bummer, you mean that it is disappointing, frustrating, or unpleasant.
example_sentences: It's a real bummer that it's raining on the day of the village fête.
bummer.usage: leave the party that turned out to be a bummer
bummer.Chinese: 离开那个很糟糕的派对

sth. doesn't justify the price.definition: If you say that something doesn't justify the price, you mean that its quality or value does not warrant the amount of money being charged for it.
example_sentences: The mediocre service at that posh restaurant certainly doesn't justify the price of the meal.
sth. doesn't justify the price.usage: only to find the new shoes don't justify the price
sth. doesn't justify the price.Chinese: 结果发现新鞋不值得这个价钱

urban area.definition: An urban area is a region characterised by high population density and extensive human-built features, typically referring to a city or town.
example_sentences: Central Manchester is a bustling urban area with a rich industrial heritage.

mobile plan.definition: A mobile plan is a contract or agreement with a mobile phone company that outlines the services, costs, and terms for using a mobile phone network.
example_sentences: I switched to a new mobile plan with EE that offers unlimited data and free roaming in Europe.
mobile plan.usage: sign up for a mobile plan
mobile plan.Chinese: 签订一个新的手机套餐

make the runoff.definition: If a candidate makes the runoff in an election, they are one of the two candidates who receive the most votes in the first round and proceed to a second round of voting.
example_sentences: The incumbent mayor made the runoff after the first round of voting, but faced a tough challenge from the opposition candidate.
make the runoff.usage: the candidate that made the runoff

take a nosedive.definition: If something takes a nosedive, it falls rapidly and dramatically.
example_sentences: The company's share price took a nosedive after the scandal broke.
take a nosedive.usage: the company's share price that took a nosedive

file one's taxes.definition: To file one's taxes means to submit the necessary documents to the tax authorities declaring one's income and calculating the amount of tax owed.
example_sentences: It's important to file your taxes on time to avoid penalties.
file one's taxes.usage: file his taxes before the deadline

tax agency.definition: A tax agency is a government department responsible for collecting taxes.
