example_sentences: The tax agency sent me a letter requesting additional information for my tax return.

payroll tax statement.definition: A payroll tax statement is a document provided by an employer that details an employee's earnings and the corresponding tax deductions.
example_sentences: I checked my payroll tax statement to verify the amount of income tax withheld.

with an open mind.definition: If you approach something with an open mind, you are receptive to new ideas and willing to consider different perspectives.
example_sentences: It's essential to approach negotiations with an open mind to find a mutually beneficial agreement.
with an open mind.usage: go to the meeting with an open mind
with an open mind.Chinese: 带着开放的心态去开会

fire truck.definition: A fire truck is a large vehicle equipped with firefighting apparatus, used by firefighters to respond to emergencies.
example_sentences: The children were excited to see the fire truck with its flashing lights.

eat sb. alive.definition: If you say someone will eat you alive, you mean they will criticise or reprimand you severely.
example_sentences: I was terrified of giving the presentation as my boss is known to eat people alive if they make mistakes.
eat sb. alive.usage: be afraid that the journalists will eat him alive
eat sb. alive.Chinese: 担心记者们会狠狠批评他

as old as time.definition: Something that is as old as time has existed for an immensely long period, often implying great antiquity.
example_sentences: The concept of good versus evil is a theme as old as time, found in countless stories and myths.
as old as time.usage: a theme that's as old as time

take a battering.definition: If something takes a battering, it suffers significant damage or harm.
example_sentences: The old cottage had taken a battering over the years, with its weathered exterior and broken windows.
take a battering.usage: the farm that took a battering in the storm
take a battering.Chinese: 在风暴中受到重创的农场

eggnog.definition: Eggnog is a sweet, creamy beverage traditionally made with milk, cream, sugar, and whipped eggs, often enjoyed during the festive season.
example_sentences: At the Christmas party, Aunt Margaret served her famous homemade eggnog, much to everyone's delight.

appoint an attorney.definition: If you appoint an attorney, you officially select them to represent you in legal matters.
example_sentences: After receiving the court summons, Mr. Thompson promptly appointed an attorney to handle his case.
appoint an attorney.usage: appoint an attorney to handle the case
appoint an attorney.Chinese: 指定一名律师处理案件

take that tone with sb..definition: If you tell someone not to take that tone with you, you are expressing displeasure at their manner of speaking to you.
example_sentences: When her son spoke rudely, Mrs. Higgins sternly said, 'Don't you dare take that tone with me, young man.'
take that tone with sb..usage: tell the student not to take that tone with the teacher
take that tone with sb..Chinese: 告诉学生不要用那种语气和说话

have got oneself a situation.definition: If you say that someone has got themselves a situation, you mean they have found themselves in a difficult or complicated circumstance.
example_sentences: After forgetting his passport at home before an international flight, Tom realised he'd got himself a situation.
have got oneself a situation.usage: realise that he's got himself a situation

20/20 vision.definition: If you have 20/20 vision, you possess normal visual acuity and can see clearly without the need for corrective lenses.
example_sentences: Despite spending hours on his computer, James maintained his 20/20 vision and didn't require glasses.

a poor vision.definition: If you have poor vision, you struggle to see clearly and may require corrective lenses or other visual aids.
example_sentences: Sarah's poor vision meant she had to sit at the front of the lecture hall to see the blackboard.

make out.definition: If you can make out something, you are able to see or distinguish it, often with some difficulty.
example_sentences: Through the thick fog, we could just make out the outline of the village church spire.
make out.usage: make out the price on the menu

blind as a bat.definition: If you say someone is as blind as a bat, you mean they have very poor eyesight.
example_sentences: Without his spectacles, old Mr. Jenkins was as blind as a bat and couldn't even read the newspaper headlines.
blind as a bat.usage: be as blind as a bat without glasses
blind as a bat.Chinese: 没有眼镜什么都看不清

blurry vision.definition: Blurry vision is a condition where one's eyesight is unclear or unfocused.
example_sentences: After working late into the night, Emma experienced blurry vision and decided to rest her eyes.

fill out the prescription.definition: If a doctor fills out a prescription, they write down the details of the medication a patient needs to take.
example_sentences: The GP carefully filled out the prescription for antibiotics and handed it to the patient.
fill out the prescription.usage: wait for the doctor to fill out the prescription

what seems to be the problem.definition: If you ask 'What seems to be the problem?', you are inquiring about the nature of an issue or difficulty someone is experiencing.
example_sentences: As the customer approached the help desk with a frown, the assistant politely asked, 'What seems to be the problem, sir?'
what seems to be the problem.usage: ask the doctor what seems to be the problem
what seems to be the problem.Chinese: 询问医生出了什么毛病

head on over somewhere.definition: If you head on over somewhere, you go to that place, often casually or informally.
example_sentences: After finishing our tea, we decided to head on over to the local pub for a pint.
head on over somewhere.usage: head on over to the pub

Fortune 500 company.definition: A Fortune 500 company is one of the 500 largest and most profitable companies in the United States, as ranked annually by Fortune magazine.
example_sentences: Despite being based in London, the British firm's success in America led to its inclusion in the Fortune 500 company list.

under someone.definition: If you are under someone in a work context, you are in a subordinate position to them in the organisational hierarchy.
example_sentences: As the new department head, Sarah had 50 employees working under her.
under someone.Chinese: 有50名员工在他的领导下工作

go on about sth..definition: If you go on about something, you talk about it excessively or for a prolonged period, often to the point of annoyance.
example_sentences: During afternoon tea, Grandpa wouldn't stop going on about the good old days, much to the amusement of his grandchildren.
go on about sth..usage: go on about the same story
